entry.title: Miscellaneous

entry.content:
Dressing table shelf - small shelf to hold jewelry and other nick-knacks on the dressing table.

Yarn holder

Calendar hook rail

Spoons

Book bat

Josie's project, not mine.  Unfortunately it wasn't quite big/heavy enough to do it's job of holding your book open while you eat breakfast etc.  It's still a successful bat though!

entry.title: Charred box
entry.summary: A simple pine box from real junk bedframe wood. By ripping the pieces and jointing I was able to get clean "quarter sawn" boards which I was hoping would work well to emphasize the grain when charred. Box before charring Charred and brushed with a…
entry.content:
A simple pine box from real junk bedframe wood.

By ripping the pieces and jointing I was able to get clean "quarter sawn" boards which I was hoping would work well to emphasize the grain when charred.

Box before charring

Charred and brushed with a wire brush to emphasize the grain texture - it still looks pretty flat in the photo but it's maybe 1mm deeper between the growth rings. 

Finished with shellac

entry.title: Couch caddy #2
entry.summary: After 5 years of daily use, I figured we could use a second one. (the original) And as it happened, I still had a piece of the same bed-frame I made the first one out of.  Not quite as nice a piece, but quite a…
entry.content:
After 5 years of daily use, I figured we could use a second one. (the original)

And as it happened, I still had a piece of the same bed-frame I made the first one out of.  Not quite as nice a piece, but quite a coincidence.

Resawed the board into 3rds, then planed and jointed and patched a the worst holes/knots.

Final result, finished with polyurethane again, which is an awful finish, but waterproof...

entry.title: Workshop Drawers
entry.summary: Drawers for screws/nails etc. Dividers in the drawers are a bit easier and hopefully more flexible than many small apothecary-style drawers.  Can also add a second "till" layer in each draw for more storage. Made from old plywood from a tabletop.  Too old, as the…
entry.content:
Drawers for screws/nails etc.

Dividers in the drawers are a bit easier and hopefully more flexible than many small apothecary-style drawers.  Can also add a second "till" layer in each draw for more storage.

Made from old plywood from a tabletop.  Too old, as the plywood was delaminating in places and needed a lot of repair and more care than I gave it.

Made the drawers first to get the dimensions for the carcase.

Should have put more thought into it, as I was trying to find a (blind) joint to work in the plywood, but the sliding dovetail doesn't play well with a drawer bottom in grooves...

entry.title: Bed lamps
entry.summary: Converted old bedside table lamps into "shoji" style lamps. Started with wood from the legs of a coffee table One lamp was made first as a prototype The difuser material was made from fairly heavy watercolour paper (140gsm) which was coated with polyurethane to make…
entry.content:
Converted old bedside table lamps into "shoji" style lamps.

Started with wood from the legs of a coffee table

One lamp was made first as a prototype

The difuser material was made from fairly heavy watercolour paper (140gsm) which was coated with polyurethane to make it translucent and more durable.

The grid pieces were cut from draw fronts, I think they are silky oak.

A measuring mistake meant that all these grids didn't end up with the right proportions, so a couple of extra horizontal members were added in.

The main lesson from the prototype was that the lamp assembly needs to be easy to remove, this was pretty easy using a screw and washer to hold the lamp in position in a rebate in the base.

entry.title: Tool chest
entry.summary: Built roughly following the Anarchists Toolchest pattern, but made from a reclaimed bed frame so the dimensions/timber choices were a bit constrained.  The sides were glued up from bed slats.  Couldn't avoid knots, but kept them away from the joints as much as possible. The…
entry.content:
Built roughly following the Anarchists Toolchest pattern, but made from a reclaimed bed frame so the dimensions/timber choices were a bit constrained.

 The sides were glued up from bed slats.  Couldn't avoid knots, but kept them away from the joints as much as possible.

The box is pretty big, but still a little smaller than the ideal dimensions (mostly in the width as there isn't quite enough room for the trays).

Missed a few photos as adding the skirts, bottom, lid etc was fun and went quickly.

Kids helped out with the painting

Crammed most of the tools in, trays are made from pretty random wood.  Runners for the trays were also made from what I had on hand that will hopefully wear well.

Rearranged everything and repurposed the old chest.

And a really good tip I got from somewhere was to stick a block of camphor in the tool chest.  It is supposed to leave a rust-preventing layer on the tools as it evaporates and condenses on the metal.  No idea if that's true, but it smells really good every time the chest is opened.

entry.title: Bathroom corner cabinet
entry.summary: A small table/cabinet for the bathroom.  Made from wood from an old family couch (might be teak). Didn't take any photos during construction, it was a bit of a weird frame and the order of assembly was not particularly well considered...
entry.content:
A small table/cabinet for the bathroom.  Made from wood from an old family couch (might be teak).

Didn't take any photos during construction, it was a bit of a weird frame and the order of assembly was not particularly well considered...

entry.title: Art supply tote box
entry.summary: A box for storing/carrying art supplies (paint tubes) modeled on a Japanese style toolbox. Similar box by John Zhu here https://youtu.be/pxa88seXsNc?si=2QYJmRWRqUD6E20g&t=567 I made this from reclaimed timber from a chest of drawers.  The wood is quite soft, but nice and light which is important so the…
entry.content:
A box for storing/carrying art supplies (paint tubes) modeled on a Japanese style toolbox.

Similar box by John Zhu here https://youtu.be/pxa88seXsNc?si=2QYJmRWRqUD6E20g&t=567

I made this from reclaimed timber from a chest of drawers.  The wood is quite soft, but nice and light which is important so the box isn't too heavy.

Preliminary design

Larger box on the bottom, with a handle.  A slightly smaller box sits on top of this as a lid.  There is also a small till in the bottom box for paint brushes etc.

Cutting and assembling the boxes

Glued up and ready to finish

Finished with boiled linseed oil and shellac

entry.content:
A small lap-table, for raising a laptop to a better height and replacing a plastic one with something nicer.

Made from the slats of an outdoor dining table.  Nice wood, but very dirty to work with...
